title: Welcome
text:
This page hosts all slides for presentations given during SPD‚Äôs Brinner and Learn series.
Each chapter title to the left is a link to a slide deck.

These slides are being developed by the SPD team.
Each deck will open in its own tab.
You may want to type ‚Äús‚Äù at the start of each deck to open the speaker notes.
Some of these slides may end up being adopted as a more formal SPD practice.

title: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done
text:
Feature Tickets

For features, try to include a user story:

e.g.¬†‚ÄúAs a registered user, I might forget my password and want to regain access to my account securely.‚Äù

When possible, supplement the user story with unambiguous acceptance criteria
crumbs: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done

title: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done
text:
Bug Tickets

For bugs, be as detailed as possible!

Often the limiting factor for fixing a bug is reproducing it.

For example:

Environment setup (OS, browser, app version, etc.)
Reproduction Steps (What precise actions lead to the bug?)
Expected behaviour (What should have happened?)
Actual behaviour (What actually happened?)
Screenshots, logs, etc.
crumbs: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done

title: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done
text:
Acceptance Criteria

What must be true for the issue to be considered complete?

Written as bullet points
Example
crumbs: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done

title: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done
text:
Definition of Done:

All acceptance criteria are met
Tests and checks pass
Documentation is updated when relevant
Code is reviewed and merged!
crumbs: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done

title: Effective Ticketing & the Definition of Done
text:
Recap

Write clear, structured tickets
Define acceptance criteria & done criteria
Use meaningful feature branch names
gh CLI simplifies GitHub workflows

Questions?

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Motivation

Developing and Deploying Apps can be difficult
The 12 Factor App methodology provides guidelines that ensure

clarity,
scalability,
maintainability

Benefits both developers and operations teams.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Why are 12 Factor Apps Important?

Consistency and predictability in application behavior.
Simplifies the development lifecycle.
Eases the process of deploying, scaling, and maintaining applications.
Promotes collaboration between development and operations (DevOps).

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Best Practices
A lot of these concepts are things that are considered best practices, but collected together.

You are probably already do a bunch of these things
You may not know you do it (it just feels right)
You may not know why you do it (it just seems to work)
You may do it because you were told to (it isn‚Äôt broken)

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Benefits for Developers

Clear guidelines for application structure and behavior.
Simplified onboarding and reduced cognitive load.
Easier debugging and local development.
Predictable dependencies and environments.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Benefits for DevOps/Operations

Streamlined deployment and automated management.
Improved reliability and faster issue resolution.
Easier monitoring and logging.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
The 12 Factors (Brief Overview)

Codebase: One codebase tracked in version control, many deploys.
Dependencies: Explicitly declare and isolate dependencies.
Config: Store configuration in the environment.
Backing Services: Treat backing services as attached resources.
Build, Release, Run: Strictly separate build and run stages.
Processes: Execute the app as one or more stateless processes.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
The 12 Factors (Brief Overview)

Port Binding: Export services via port binding.
Concurrency: Scale out via the process model.
Disposability: Maximize robustness with fast startup and graceful shutdown.
Dev/Prod Parity: Keep development, staging, and production similar.
Logs: Treat logs as event streams.
Admin Processes: Run admin tasks as one-off processes.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Examples of Common Pitfalls

Configuration hardcoded in source code.
Dependencies not clearly defined or versioned.
Stateful processes causing unpredictable behavior.
Significant differences between development and production environments.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Getting Started with 12 Factor Apps

Review your current projects against the 12 factors.
Incrementally adopt factors as you enhance or refactor projects.
Foster collaboration and awareness across development and operations teams.

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
Enable branch protection rules

Protect main (and any other long-lived branches)
Require pull requests before merging
Require minimum 1 approving review
Enforce status checks (CI/CD pipelines, linting, tests)

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
GitHub Flow

One long-lived branch: main
feature branch ‚Üí PR ‚Üí Merge to main
Simple
Best for continuous delivery
Deploy immediately after merge to main

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
GitFlow

Long-lived branches: main, develop
Short-lived branches: release, hotfix, feature
feature branch -> PR -> Merge to develop
release branch or hotfix -> PR -> Merge to main and develop
Better for large-scale projects, many devs, scheduled releases

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
üö´ What makes a PR bad?

Large & difficult to review
Many unrelated changes
Poor or no description
Unclear commit history
Fails CI/CD checks
Lacks necessary tests

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
‚úÖ How to improve PRs

Keep PRs small and focused
Provide a clear summary & context
Write meaningful commit messages
Ensure automated checks pass before requesting review
Add relevant tests & documentation
Explain how a reviewer can test your changes

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
üö´ Common bad practices

Superficial LGTM approvals
Excessively nitpicky comments
Review lacks a clear status (ie. ‚ÄúApproved‚Äù, ‚ÄúRequest Changes‚Äù, ‚ÄúClose Recommendation‚Äù)

title: GitHub Best Practices
text:
‚úÖ How to review effectively

Clearly state your status: ‚ÄúApproved‚Äù, ‚ÄúRequest Changes‚Äù, ‚ÄúClose Recommendation‚Äù
Nitpicky or non-blocking comments should be clearly marked
Be constructive and specific
Validate logic, security, performance
Check for coding standards and test coverage
Ensure documentation is updated when necessary

title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
text:
Step 1: Write a Test (Red Phase)

Identify a small, testable unit of functionality.
Write a test that asserts the expected behavior.
Run the test (it should fail since the implementation doesn‚Äôt exist yet).


import pytest

def test_addition():
    assert add(2, 3) == 5  # Function doesn't exist yet

title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
section: Step 2: Write Minimal Code to Pass the Test (Green Phase)
text:
Step 2: Write Minimal Code to Pass the Test (Green Phase)

Implement only the necessary code to make the test pass.


def add(a, b):
    return a + b


Run the test again (it should pass now).

title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
text:
Step 3: Refactor the Code (Refactor Phase)

Clean up the implementation without changing behavior.
Ensure all tests still pass after refactoring.


def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    return a + b  # Adding types
